Originally, the area surrounding what is now known as Sigiriya, or "Lion Rock," served as a residence for Buddhist monks, established as the first Buddhist monastery in Sri Lanka somewhere between the 3rd and 1st centuries BC. Numerous caves in the vicinity still feature remnants of inscriptions from that ancient era. The site's purpose shifted dramatically around the 5th century AD when King Kashyapa I seized the throne. Fearing retaliation from his half-brother, he moved his capital here, transforming the monastic site into a sophisticated urban complex and an imposing, defensive fortress with a palace atop the rock. The ascent to the summit can be divided into four main segments. The first three are characterized by gentle inclines through the elaborate water and boulder gardens at the base. The final segment of the climb, however, is a challenging journey up a modern steel staircase attached to the sheer rock face, comprising around 1,200 steps. For those with a fear of heights, it's best to avoid looking down. Today, only the massive, intricately carved lion's paws remain at the base of this final staircase; the head, body, and shoulders of the colossal brick-and-plaster lion gateway have long since collapsed and disappeared over time. The initial ascent and descent share the same path for the first half of the journey. At the very top, while there are no standing structures, you can explore the preserved ancient foundations of the royal palace. You will be amply rewarded with bountiful, panoramic vistas of the surrounding jungle and landscape. A separate, one-way descent leads you past a spiral staircase that shouldn't be missed, as it provides access to a sheltered cave with beautifully preserved, vibrant wall paintings of celestial maidens, known as the Sigiriya Damsels. There was a guard in there to ensure no photos are taken.

Apart from its UNESCO World Heritage status, Sigiriya is primarily a symbol and a major landmark of Sri Lanka. Coming to the island and not seeing Sigiriya is like doing without Paris in France. Taking advantage of this, the authorities set the price of tickets beyond world standards. 35 USD. For a family of three, that's a sensitive $105. I always compare it to the Louvre. There's a 22 euro ticket. Plus, at the Louvre, shoot wherever you want, but here you can only look at the maidens of Sigiriya. With your eyes, not your smartphone lens... But tourists are obviously not deterred. Tourists come from all over the island. We didn't get long-- from Dambulla. Sigiriya is a giant 183-metre-long stationary rock in the middle of the jungle. The name means "Lion Rock" in Sinhala. The truth is that only two paws remain of the giant lion that once existed. The paws, though, still have to be reached. From the parking lot and entrance, the path to the cliff runs through the water gardens. In the time of the murderous king Cassapus, who made Sigiriya his capital, there were fountains that were supplied with water from the tanks on top of the rock. By hand slaves. Then comes the terrace park. Here in the time of Cassapus in the fifth century stood houses whose foundations were huge stones, past which you walk on your way to the summit. Legs. These aren't Chinese Huangshan or Zhangjiajie with their funiculars and elevators. Only feet up the stairs here. Halfway to the summit, the dilemma is whether to go up or to the right. At the top of the mountain, to the right are the famous frescoes of Sigiriya. On your way up, you'll see the famous lion's legs found by English archaeologists under Bell in 1898. On the last section, the stairs are quite steep, though generally safe. Unfortunately, only the foundations remain of the Kassap Palace and the rest of the structures. And tanks. The reward for climbing up will be views of the surrounding jungle. To see the frescoes of Sigiriya now, you have to go downstairs and follow the stairs that follow the wall to the right. You'll have to wait in line on the stairs, because the cave, which is closed to the sun, doesn't hold too many people. Few of the murals remain: out of about 500, only 19 images of women remain. But what! They represent the ancient Indian ideal of beauty: proper facial oval, almond-shaped eyes, eagle nose, full lips, lush breasts, thin waist. Scientists can't agree whether it's the king's wives or the Ansar maidens in heaven. It is believed that since the 1930s the frescoes have dimmed, so it is not possible to photograph. Sadness...

An ancient ruin almost 1500 years old or older, the rock fortress is a must visit while you are in Sri Lanka. The hill top fortress is very well preserved with the ancient brick wall of the seven story wooden palace of King Kasyapa still in good condition. According to my guide/driver, the lions paw is not a lion but the claws of the mythical bird used by King Ravana to abduct Sita. Difficult to climb the steep steel steps, the view from the top with jungle all around is amazing. The entry fee for the monument @35 USD for foreigners is quite steep. After climbing almost 1000 steps on the steel ladder which needs urgent repairs and a fresh coat of weather proof paint, the hill top is exposed to strong winds. It is suggested that strong guard rails could be provided at the hill top for the safety of the visitors. It is also suggested that a chair lift / cable car could be constructed for the visitors. It is also suggested that separate entry / exit stair case/routes could  be constructed for the convenience of the visitors  to avoid the long traffic snarls at the lions paws entrance area. It is also suggested that the authorities could provide a direct descend stair case to the cave paintings instead of compelling the weary visitor to climb another 200 steps by a spiral staircase to reach the fresco cave. It is also suggested that non-flash photography may be restored at the cave. A photograph of the re-constructed visuals of the fort complex could be displayed at the hill top. A must visit monument while you are  visiting Sri Lanka. Expensive. Recommended.

It is a rocky mountain about 200 meters high, and the top of it is the site of a former royal palace. From the west entrance near the museum to the premises. Passing through gardens with ponds and waterways (remains), and passing through a passageway through the rock face of Sigiriya Rock, the road enters in front of the "Lion Gate", the entrance to the ruins of the Royal Palace. Today it has only the lion's paws, but it is said that it once had a head whose mouth served as the entrance to the royal palace. An iron staircase leads from "Lion Gate" to the top. It's so narrow that you can see right under it, so people with a fear of heights might not be able to do it. No buildings remain on the site of the royal palace at the top, but brick building foundations, thrones, and other structures remain. The view is very good and you can see the surrounding rainforest. Back at the Lion Gate, at the top of the spiral staircase beyond the mirror wall is Sigiriya Lady, a fresco painted on a rock face. Filming used to be allowed, but for conservation purposes it was banned in 2015.

After Kashyapa's death, Sigiriya served as a Buddhist monastery until about the 14th century. Architecture: Sigiriya is admired for its sophisticated urban planning, water gardens, frescoes (beautiful ancient paintings), the famous "Mirror Wall" (a highly polished wall with ancient inscriptions and graffiti), and the impressive "Lion Gate" at the entrance to the final climb to the summit. The rock: The rock itself is nearly 200 meters (660 feet) high and offers spectacular views from the top. The climb involves navigating a series of steep staircases and pathways. The wall freezes are now covered and you have to go up metal stairs. No photographs as there are few left, thanks to vandalism. Worst aspect? Negotiating your way through the souvenir hustlers, but be firm and keep walking. I was glad I did this - and I certainly felt personal satisfaction afterwards - as well as being very tired and sweaty!!

The site features a massive rock plateau that rises nearly 200 meters (660 feet) above the surrounding landscape, offering breathtaking panoramic views. Sigiriya is believed to have been the royal residence of King Kassapa I, who reigned in the 5th century AD. The fortress is famous for its well-preserved frescoes, the Lion‚Äôs Gate, and the Mirror Wall, which is covered in ancient inscriptions. Visitors must climb a series of steps to reach the summit, where the remnants of the royal palace and its surroundings can be explored. The site is historically significant for both its architectural and cultural value, as well as for its stunning natural beauty. Sigiriya is often considered one of the best-preserved examples of ancient urban planning.

According to historical chronicles, Kashyapa, the second son of King Datusena, wanting to take the crown over his elder brother kills his father. Mugalan, the elder brother flees to India. Kashyapa is shunned by the clergy and the people of Anuradhapura, the capital city at the time. Due to this and also in fear of an invasion by his brother, he flees to Sigiriya rock, builds a fortress atop the rock and rules from there. Eighteen years later, Mugalan returns with an army and Kashyapa (for some unexplained reason, decides to meet his brother outside the very fortress which he supposedly built to withstand an invasion) and dies in battle.... Sigiriya is abandoned and the capital city shifts back to Anuradhapura. But when you see this 5th century architectural marvel you would be left doubting the truth of this story. Because Sigirya is so much more than a fortress built for protection. While it has the usual walls and moats it is very evident that it has been built with an eye for "all things beautiful".... Nowadays you enter Sigiriya from its Western entrance. No excavations have been done on the eastern side yet. As you enter you walk through a symmetrical water garden. Even here, full excavations have been done only on one side. But you can still see ponds of various shapes and sizes and even fountains that function to this day. Once you pass the water garden, you go through the "Boulder garden" where the pathway to top and various ancillary buildings have been constructed using the natural placement of the boulders. Then you get to the Terrace Garden where you see the famous lion paws. The entrance to the top of the rock lies between the paws. Once you get to the top there are ruins of the palace, ponds and panoramic views. On your way back, you will take a different route and pass through the "Mirror Wall" a 5th century construction, on which 8th - 12th century visitors to Sigiriya have written 100s of poems about the beauty they have witnessed.....  and unlike the scrawls of visitors these days, these poems are considered as having high literary value... Next you come to what is probably Sigiriya is most famous for... it's cave paintings. According to archeologists and also the poems on the mirror wall, at one point, the entire western facade of the rock was likely covered in the same paintings.... there are various interpretations of who the ladies in the paintings are, some say they are ladies of Kashyapa's harem, some say they are noble ladies and some say they are angles from the sky.... Tips for visiting: -Sigiriya deserves its palce as the eighth wonder of the world, but reading up on it before before visiting will greatly enhance your experience as neither the sad looking museum nor the guides will do justice King Kashyapa's visionary work. -There is an entrance fee. A reasonable amount for locals. Not sure about the fee for foreigners. -You take two different path ways to go up and down, hence its advisable to check out all the places on the way up to avoid missing them on the way down. -This is a relatively easy climb. Took us about 45 mts to climb with all the detours and 20 mts to climb down. Plus it's not a religious place, so you can wear anything suitable for the weather/ hiking. -Anything amazing will loose its luster if you are sweating buckets ;) so early morning or evening would be a better idea, subject to opening and closing hours. -There are wild elephants on the access roads to Sigiriya specially at night and in the early mornings. So, if you are climbing Sigiriya to see the sunrise, do take the advice of a guide. -There have always been wasps nests near the lion paws, I remember seeing them even when I was a kid. There have been a couple of rare instances in which attacks have occurred, most recent being this August. This usually happens when the crowd gets too nosiy. Here, the tip would be to climb on a less crowded day, which would also help in avoiding queues.

Sigiriya, also known as Lion Rock, is a magnificent 5th-century fortress built by King Kasyapa after seizing the throne. Located 170km from Colombo, this UNESCO World Heritage Site is often regarded as the 8th wonder of the world. The fortress stands 600 feet high and is surrounded by moats and ramparts, built to protect the king from his half-brother‚Äôs return. At the base lies the Pleasure Gardens, featuring water gardens, bathing ponds, and boulder gardens. The famous Sigiriya Frescos, depicting beautiful ladies with vibrant colors, adorn the rock's western face. Originally, over 500 paintings covered this area, making it the largest mural ever attempted. The Mirror Wall, once polished to reflect like glass, bears ancient verses written by visitors, expressing their admiration for the frescoes. The lion‚Äôs paws at the rock‚Äôs entrance hint at the grand lion statue that once stood guard. At the summit, the ruins of the Royal Palace, complete with water tanks and a small stupa, offer stunning views, making Sigiriya a true marvel of ancient Sri Lankan ingenuity.

Only when we reached the top did we realise we had climbed the more arduous pidurangala rock and that we were viewing the more spectacular sigiriya mountain just across the landscape. The rainy season had begun and we prayed the rains would hold on for a few hours the next day just like it did that evening. Sigiriya is a guided tour and not so dangerous/tiring. What tests your nerves is the steep metal staircase which can turn your legs to jelly if u try to look down. The schoolchildren aged lesser than 10 years climbing up with us with zero fear made us not want to quit. We preserved and reached the top in about 40 mins with a break at the lions paws. The view from the top is beautiful but I guess it feels much more beautiful because you have conquered your own fears and feel like an Olympian ! The way down the metal staircase is not easy and then down the narrow and sandy cemented steps . The walk to the see the frescoes ( atop a spiral staircase) can still feel ethereal. Amazing views and rightly Sri Lanka's #1 attraction.  Takes about 30-40 mins to climb up but the steps are steep so avoid hottest periods.  Best done after 4pm. Every time I bring guests to Sigiriya, I‚Äôm reminded of why this ancient marvel is a must-see for anyone visiting Sri Lanka. Sigiriya, or Lion Rock, is not just a historical site‚Äîit's a journey back in time. The moment you start climbing, you‚Äôre stepping into a world where ancient engineering meets breathtaking natural beauty. The ascent to the summit is both exhilarating and rewarding. The Lion‚Äôs Gate, with its impressive lion paws, is a powerful symbol of the fortress‚Äôs former grandeur. The Mirror Wall, once polished to reflect the king‚Äôs image, now tells stories through ancient inscriptions and poems left by past visitors. And let‚Äôs not forget the stunning frescoes that still dazzle with their vibrant colors and artistic detail. The panoramic views from the top are simply unparalleled. From up there, you can see the lush Sri Lankan countryside stretch out in every direction, providing a stunning backdrop to the ruins of the ancient palace. It‚Äôs a moment that truly takes your breath away. What I love most about guiding tours at Sigiriya is the opportunity to share the rich history and legends with visitors. Every corner of the site has its own story, and seeing the wonder and excitement in my guests‚Äô eyes as they learn about this incredible place is always a highlight. For anyone looking to immerse themselves in Sri Lanka‚Äôs heritage and experience one of its most iconic landmarks, Sigiriya is an absolute must. Whether you're a history enthusiast or simply a traveler seeking stunning views, this site offers something special for everyone.
Very rewarding. A must to do. It is wise to go early in the morning, because it is very hot. A good condition is an advantage, but certainly not required. Once at the top the view is phenomenal!

The place is unique: it is the archaeological remains of the palace-fortress wanted by King Kasyapa (477-495 AD), when he decided to found the capital of his kingdom in Sigirya, placed partly on a steep magmatic rock about 200 m high. The view from below is amazing and pairs with the pictures from above. The climb is tiring due to the heat but in itself it is short (about 20 minutes) on comfortable metal stairs (stone stairs are more uncomfortable, the first ones you meet. The two mighty stone lion legs really make you imagine how amazing the palace must have been and the frescoes, although limited, are very beautiful and sensual. In addition, the view, from the top, sweeps over endless carpets of trees, interrupted by lakes and streams and low mountains. The museum is also interesting. But Sigirya deserves the highest rating both for the incredibly exaggerated price ($36 each without discounts for families or students or anything else) and because at such a price you would definitely expect a much better service (for example the included guide or a very modern museum). I am sorry to write this but after the 30 Dollars of Pollonaruwa and the 36 Dollars of Sigyria, we decided to continue our journey carefully avoiding all the plucking places of Sri Lanka.
Greate location and beautiful place we met in our life. Good for hikers and educational place for everyone. Historical sign in sri lanka

spectacular amazing view with cool fresh breeze blended with sound of nature with stunning and mesmerising memories  adding to your life adventure and explore private guided tour  with National Tourist Guide Ajja

We recently climbed Lion Rock and the experience was really beautiful. Admission costs $35, but children under 6 do not pay, which is very valuable for families. At times, the step can be quite congested, but this does not detract from the interest of the visit. The views are simply splendid and really worth the effort. I recommend this experience to those looking for a unique adventure with breathtaking scenery.
Fantastic experience climbing the Sigiriya Rock! Do it early to avoid the heat and the crowds. The climb was not challenging either.

A steady climb up lots of steps and then the final push is up a metal staircase fixed to the rock. The views from the top are incredible, as are the ruins. It was very busy when we went up, about 08:30 in the morning, so be prepared for some queues and walking up slowly behind others. On the way back down you can go up a spiral staircase and see some ancient cave paintings. The museum at the car park is also worth visiting, we did this after climbing the rock so keep your ticket for entry. There are a lot of guides who want to show you around and tell you about the history. The path is really clear, just follow the hordes of people in front of you, so you really don‚Äôt need a guide unless you really want someone talking to you all the way around. It is quite expensive at $35 each for foreigners. If you have the money then it‚Äôs worth doing but if not go to Pigtuangala rock instead. It‚Äôs quieter, the views are equally spectacular if not better and it only costs 1000 LKR each.

I was worried about whether it not is be able to climb the rock after reading many reviews It was fine we went fairly early in the day and just took it slowly. There were places to be real out and have a rest if you needed to and well worth the effort, so glad I did it!

We went up early to see the sunrise, but it was cloudy‚Ä¶ Nevertheless, we enjoyed the visit. Visit this place early to enjoy the dawn and sunrise. A head for heights is needed as you climb the steps, ok if you don‚Äôt look down. After the climb the 360 degree view from the top is wonderful and well worth the early start and 1200 or so steps.

The wind was strong, so we climbed the stairs, which were narrow and made us feel as if we were about to fall. The view from the ruins of the castle at the top was amazing and impressive. The descending stairs were scarier than the ascent.
Amazing place, Accomodate, swimming, relaxing, safaris and many more things to do.  Very attractive place. All can enjoy with family or solo.
Great climb Great views If you are fit you can cover this is less than. 30 minutes. Dont be daunted by the height. Its great when you reach the top.

We did a climb which took around 30-40mins to reach the top and we were mesmirzed with the views. The stairs can be a bit intimidating and scary but its not tough. Sigiriya along with the Train to Ella is the most emblematic of Sri Lanka. It is a beautiful place, once upstairs, that costs to raise the views are priceless.

Sigiriya, also known as Lion Rock, is an ancient rock fortress located in the central Matale District of Sri Lanka. It features the ruins of a palace complex built by King Kashyapa (477‚Äì495 AD) on top of a 200-meter-high rock. The site is renowned for its elaborate frescoes, extensive gardens, and a large gate in the shape of a lion. Sigiriya is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and is considered one of the best-preserved examples of ancient urban planning.

The fortress itself is very impressive and the history behind it intriguing. The views from the top are breathtaking! The 1200 steps are achievable but you will struggle if you are scared of heights! I couldn't argue with the sheer monolithic beauty of this rock, standing high in a sea of green. I so wanted to climb to the top and enjoy the view. I was even prepared to pay the extortionate price reserved especially for gullible tourists. But, as I made my way up the path it became increasingly busy. By the time I'd arrived at the lion's feet, the place had turned into a major town centre on a Saturday night. Throngs of people, mostly local, all queuing up the metal steps bolted to the side of the rock. Entire families, some carrying babies. I think I even saw a pushchair being bundled up. Suddenly, those metal steps didn't look too sturdy. I chickened out. I guess the journey to heaven isn't for me. Still, at least I didn't get attacked by wasps.

My review is no different to so many others. The climb up is hard, though some people will manage well enough. Not me! I'm short, and the climbing (bearing in mind the humidity too) is hard on my legs. We were there around 6.30am, not crowded, so that helped. Once we got to the Lion's Paws I said I couldn't keep going, but no surprise, I was persuaded to keep going, and the steel steps with handrails were much easier, and I DID make it! Down was still tough for me- my legs were like jelly, but the guide held my arm to be sure I didn't drop. Like any attraction all over the world, no-one HAS to do it, it isn't a 'you must do it' thing, but anyone who keeps going like me will be well rewarded. :)

One of the best place to visit in Srilanka. We climbed this in the early morning around 6.30 as soon as it is opened for visitors and mainly to avoid the heat and sun stroke. What a challenge! We started the ascent at 6 am, it was already quite hot and humid. 1200 stairs up to the highest point in 35 minutes. But it is worth it - getting up early and all the sweat! Family back within the hour.  Those that couldn't do the climb weren't allowed to spend time in the beautiful park.  Who knows what was in the museum.  We drove around the rock but there wasn't much to see.  Disappointing

Everything is well summarized in the previous comments, bring water (there is none on sale after entry) because it is very hot, there is little shade and even for people in good shape it It's quite physical. Of course it is possible to make several stops and still enjoy it without climbing to the top (even if that is a shame). Wonderful trip. Getting there is not easy but the trip is definitely worth the trip. When you get to the top you queue up a spectacular view. The only advice is to definitely go there without hesitation.

Climbing Sigiriya is doable and definitely worth it! Whilst the metal steps, seemingly precariously attached to the outside of the rock, seem rickety, the view from the top is phenomenal. It is also worth the terrifying climb up the spiral staircase to aee the remaining frescoes.

In single line ' A magnificent historical monument'. For people with young kids be prepared, The climb to the top can be challenging. You can take multiple stops in between but again you will not find drink and water shops on top, carry sufficient water with you. After approx 1000 steps you will reach lions feet and from there it would be 500 steps to reach the top, it's totally worth it for the panoramic scenery. The gardens and water features add to the charm of this UNESCO World Heritage Site. Overall, it's a must-visit site. It could get sunny from 9am onwards so an early ascend will help. Beware of monkeys near lions feet, do not expose any food or try feeding them.
As you approach you realise how high it is You need to be very very fit to climb to the top Even if you can not climb to the top the grounds are lovely to see and lower level interesting

This is the most beautiful journey. The impressions cannot be described in words. It was not easy to physically climb the plateau, but it was worth it. Climb to the top - you won't regret it! The views from the top are worth the climb.  You'll need a reasonable level of fitness to get to the top, especially in the heat. Looking at Sigiriya in the distance was daunting, and even commencing the climb, I was hoping  we would make it to the top ok! I have visited This Attraction on Last January .it was my Family Trip.The lion Rock fortress was one of my amazing Place which I ever Visited on Srilanka.

Great day out! Make sure you start your climb early, as it gets very hot at midday. The climb is a bit physically demanding, but there are plenty of spots to stop and rest along the way. Once you‚Äôre through the entry gate, there is no opportunity to buy water until you exit. You also don‚Äôt need a guide to climb the rock. There are lots of guides in the carpark who will try to approach you and offer tours (for a large fee) but they are not necessary.

We had Sigiriya on our tour program in the evening of the first day, immediately after arrival, but the guide advised us to postpone the visit to the next morning. And he did it very well! The climb up is not easy, you have to climb 170 meters, the stairs are both ancient, preserved, and steel, hung on the rocks. Both on the way up and at the very top the views are amazing! In the fifteen hundred years that have passed since the construction of the royal palace on top of this rock, quite a lot has been preserved, including a pool of water! What a gem: grandiose frescoes painted on the rock, you can see them when descending on the way back.

So I am petrified of heights.  This is no mean feat.  However, we used a local guide as well as a helper who without, I could not have done this.  our driver advised us to do the climb early, so we arrived at 05.15 and started the climb at 05.30.  We saw the sunrise which was incredible and then made the horrific climb down.  Again with Seine on my arm the whole way, I did it!  I cant tell you how fantastic I feel, so please if you're scared, then don't just not do it, get help and go for it!

Tip # 1 - go EARLY, like 5:30 am, to beat the heat and the crowds. Tip # 2 - take water along and take breaks. I found the hike very strenuous and definitely not for people who are afraid of heights. I made it to the second level and skipped the third level. I am recovering from hip surgery, so I was happy with what I achieved. That said, even from the 2. level you have beautiful views.
An ascent of more than 1000 steps to the summit. A sporty walk, but worth the detour. An exceptional and unique view. A return to history full of emotions. FABULOUS!!!

The Hill Fort is a must do if you are in this part of Sri Lanka. If you are concerned about heights but want to get to the top, then I'd advise organising a guide at the bottom. We didn't, and my wife was pounced on by a guide on the last section. He then stayed with us as the walk down can also be a bit difficult (if you don't like heights). By the time we got to the bottom, we were pretty hot, and my bartering skills were non existant. The climb up took less than 30 minutes - we are in our late 50's - so it's not that demanding. My one complaint is that tourists are charged 36 USD each whilst locals pay pennies. I'm okay with paying more, but they should provide decent Western facilities at the booking office if they are charging us so much. The toilets were vile, which I think is disgraceful for such important site.

It literally costs you blood, sweat and tears, but the view up there is worth this hellish climb... A climb of 1200 steps in a leaden sun is not an everyday thing... but we thoroughly enjoyed it once at the top

It's THE thing to do in Sri Lanka and perhaps the most impressive place. This 370m red and ocher monolith is worth the trip. You have to go there as early as possible to avoid the crowds and the hot weather. Then, take your time to climb all these steps and don't look in the 2nd part after the Lion's paws. If you are prone to vertigo, avoid this last part. The view at the top is incredible and the remains of the fortress give a small idea of the megalomania of the king who took refuge there. A large swimming pool and remains of walls remain.

While in Sri Lanka this is a must visit place. It has lots of history ranging from King Kashyapa to King Ravana. It is worth the visit. The climb is steep but one must go on. The entry fees is quite high and one needs to have a passport for entry ticket purchase. There are paintings, mirror wall, water tank on the top which are unique to this place.

If you go with your car, approch from the western gate, which is the main gate. As the tickets for forigners are sold in the museum, go take a look there as well. It was very informative. Take water with you, lesser people when uv index is high, many started to climb after 16 o'clock when we came down. There are pleanty of places in the shadow you can rest. Still, there is a bit climb. Upstairs the view is a blast. Definitaly recommend.

Not for the faint hearted or anyone afraid of heights, the staircase is a bit DIY and you can see the drop through the steps. Would strongly recommend going before dawn. We went at 7am which was a bit late, by the time we were coming back (9:30/10) it was already too hot. Don‚Äôt massively recommend the museum, but if you do it, go after the climb so that you‚Äôve gone up in the cooler weather. The hike was hard at times and there‚Äôs no where to buy snacks or water once you‚Äôre in, so bring enough water for the whole two hours.

Sri Lanka was a good surprise as it has the views, landscape, and history as well especially the Sigiriya story that we appreciated even more after climbing the top and seeing the ruins of the empire that once was there. It's probably one of my favorite historical stories to date. But the climb is not for the faint-hearted and requires a certain level of strength and stamina to get to the top.

Venturing to Sigiriya Lion Rock was an awe-inspiring journey into Sri Lanka's rich history and culture. At $30 per ticket with a generous 50% discount for kids, it offers fantastic value for the experience it delivers. Our ascent to the top took around two to three hours, which was both exhilarating and rewarding. I highly recommend timing your visit to catch either the mesmerizing sunset or the enchanting sunrise. The play of light on the ancient rock formations and the surrounding landscapes is simply breathtaking. The views from the summit are unparalleled, offering a glimpse into the historical significance and natural beauty of the area. The ascent itself is an adventure, with well-preserved staircases, ancient frescoes, and awe-inspiring rock formations along the way. It's a testament to the ingenuity and architectural prowess of ancient civilizations. For families, this is an educational and immersive experience that will captivate both children and adults alike. The site's accessibility and well-maintained facilities make it suitable for visitors of all ages. In conclusion, a visit to Sigiriya Lion Rock is a must-do for anyone traveling to Sri Lanka. It's not just a climb; it's a journey through time and culture that leaves a lasting impression.

A tough climb, but certainly doable. First climb up via various terraces. That's the hard part, because it's very uneven. From the plateau with the lion's claws, take the stairs to the top for a great view. The palace once stood on top of the mountain. On the way back you will see beautiful murals.

Even though the climbing is famous, there is something interesting and beautiful at every level. It is impossible not to admire the changing view and greenery as you climb the stairs from the water pools at the foot. I did not climb to the top, but it was worth every step I climbed.

A Must-See if you are interested in history, art or nature! The ancient fortress is really impressive with unique art and awsome viewpoints üòÉ (good footgear recommended) Sigiriya was part of my wonderful tour in January 2024, tailored perfectly to my needs and wishes.  Temples, rock temples, archaelogical sites, jungle & elephants, culture, cooking, ... My driver, Rohan, realised instantly what I liked most and showed me, in addition to the well known places, also some hidden strong sites. He is not only a very good and safe driver but also a skilled and flexible guide, sometimes a guard and, fortunately, a good pal. He also gave veritable insider hints, trained my bargaining skills and found the hotels and restaurants most suitable for me. I am very happy about that rich tour! If you are looking for a good tour guide, just talk to Rohan about your time, your budget and your ideas and he will develop a plan together with you. WhattsApp Rohan: +94775610246 NS TOURS, nishantha3me@gmail.com Negombo, Sri Lanka

My god I thought I would die! But I did it!! I actually thought it would be worse but surprisingly we took our time and rested at every viewpoint. It was quite challenging for someone as unfit as I am, although there‚Äôs no competition and the garden grounds were also beautiful and worth strolling around.

Ascent in 25 minutes with an average physical condition, but accessible to the vast majority because they are stairs either in the rock (irregular) or metal. The climb can be steep, but take your time if necessary. Don't forget your water bottle! Unfortunately, we were not able to see the sunrise because the rock was in the clouds, however the site is surprising, and the points of interest to see on the way down are superb (the young ladies are magnificent, breathtaking!). Enjoy the garden after the descent and not at the start of the visit, as the site quickly fills up with visitors.

A visit to Sigiriya is on most people‚Äôs itinerary when touring Sri Lanka. Our visit was on a Saturday and we arrived about 8-30am, it was busy but not uncomfortably so. Having already read up on the site, we skipped to the museum, which is by the ticket office, to get the rock climbed before it got too hot. The climb itself was not too bad, my wife does not like heights but was determined to get to the top, so whilst we were on the metal step section, just didn‚Äôt look down!  Once at the top it is interesting to walk round and see the remains of the various developments, note you get a helpful leaflet with your ticket, which provides some useful information. The views from the top are also spectacular. Although there are some monkeys around, they did not seem to trouble the tourists. It may seem obvious but there are no facilities within the complex, so take plenty of water and any other refreshments that you may need.
Don't be scared by hundred steps or weather changes. At the top your soul and body will be weakened by the view and the story. A guide is more than suggested to fully enjoy your visit.
amazing view and the green jungles are awsome the lion rock was build 2500 years ago. its one of the 7th number of wonder. srilanka wonder of asia

We had a awesome day out hiking to the top. Met a lot of friendly visitorrs around the world along the way. Point to note: Entry fee in Feb '24 is USD 36 pp. Visitors from SAARC countries get a 50% discount provided they bring the ORIGINAL passport (No PHOTOCOPIES accepted).

On my second day in Sri Lanka, I embarked on a captivating journey to the iconic Sigiriya Rock Fortress and a charming village tour guided by a knowledgeable local guide. The day began with an awe-inspiring ascent of Sigiriya, a UNESCO World Heritage site known for its remarkable rock fortress perched atop a towering plateau. As I climbed the ancient staircases and marvelled at the stunning frescoes and expansive views, I couldn't help but feel a sense of wonder at the ingenuity of the ancient builders who constructed this architectural marvel. After descending from Sigiriya, I embarked on a village tour led by a friendly and insightful guide Lochana. Venturing off the beaten path, we explored lush paddy fields, vibrant fruit orchards, and quaint rural settlements, immersing ourselves in the rhythm of daily village life. Along the way, the guide shared fascinating anecdotes and historical insights, offering a deeper understanding of Sri Lanka's rich cultural heritage. The highlight of the village tour was undoubtedly the warm hospitality of the local villagers, who welcomed us with open arms and genuine smiles. From sampling delicious home-cooked meals to trying my hand at traditional crafts, every interaction was a heartwarming reminder of the warmth and generosity of the Sri Lankan people. The entrance fee for Sigiriya was 30 USD per adult and half price for kids. Additionally, the village tour was priced at 15 USD per person. Overall, my second day in Sri Lanka was a delightful blend of adventure, history, and cultural immersion. The awe-inspiring ascent of Sigiriya and the enriching village tour provided me with unforgettable memories and a deeper appreciation for the beauty and diversity of this remarkable country. Highly recommend for any travellers.

Wonderful complex, the king must have felt safe there. Climbing up through the water gardens is wonderful and leaves many impressions. After that, however, the climbing of the stairs begins and it is quite an adventure. If I counted correctly, there are about 1200 steps up and the same number down. There were too many people, so I had to wonder whether the railings attached to the outside of the rock face would be able to bear the weight.

It is absolutely as amazing as it looks. Head up in late afternoon for the slowest time and a terrific sunset view, but heads up there are some wall paintings you can miss as the site closes at 530 (tho tourists are allowed to hang around about an hour longer). To make sure you don‚Äôt miss these, take the first fork to the right after the wall of stairs, climb up to see pics, then head back to continue your ascent. We websites to catch this on the way back and just missed it. Heads up the ascent is brief but BRUTAL. Do not attempt in middle of the afternoon, and bring plenty of water, but careful with it as there are no restrooms the entire time. Doable without hassleif you bring a couple energy drinks and pace yourself, or if you are reasonably fit.

This place has great views and the longer you look around the more you can see. It is important to go early because the more people the more treacherous and dull it becomes. There are a lot of people who don‚Äôt take great care on the steps so you need to be aware of others. You do need to be physically capable to get up this, it took my wife and I 30 minutes as she needed breaks and is reasonably fit but it is a big elevation gain over a very short period and approximately 1km walk in total. It is expensive but it has to be done i guess!
Magnificent fortress with incredible views at the top. The climb of the stairs in the last part is impressive considering the crowds even at 8am in the morning!

I did a private 10 day tour of the highlights of Sri Lanka so can not recommend any of the various tours.  I can recommend hiring a private driver for at least a few days to get you to the most interesting sites in a very efficient way. With the driver we also stopped to get coconut juice or try local curd and honey or take pictures of elephants and monitor lizards. With several people it is cost-effective and you absolutely do NOT want to try and rent a car and drive yourself unless you have a lot of previous experience with this type of traffic.  Anyway‚Ä¶Sigirya is another must do excursion. There is quite a climb to the top, up rock and cement steps and up metal steps attached to the cliff face. If heights bother you, be aware. Hiring a guide is not expensive $12-15, and you will get lots of information. Or you can read up ahead of time and get the same info. Very interesting history of parricide, sibling rivalry, family feuds, and a playboy king who lived up top with his one wife and 500 concubines. Amazing use of water for heating and cooling, with conduits and pools and sanitary systems.  Great views.  Fascinating history. It reminded me a little of Egyptian ruins, and the magnificence that has been eroded by time and weather.
They are exploiting visitors with the price of entrance. What is nice is nature and generally the place which is impressive.  They had a civilization, but was way inferior to Greeks and Romans.

It's truly one of the wonders of the world. Before my trip I researched numerous attractions in Sri Lanka, and Sigiriya consistently emerged as a top recommendation - it's undoubtedly an icon of Sri Lanka tourism, the site is breathtakingly beautiful and offers a wealth of historical and cultural insights.

Getting there at the crack of dawn is a MUST - avoids the crowds (and the heat), and you can watch the sun rise from the top. This is a magical place steeped in history, and the scale of construction (now mainly ruins) is beyond belief given the limited resources (mechanical and technical) available all those many many years ago. This place is has a surreal quality - breathtaking in its grandeur, scale and inaccessibility, and on an emotional scale to that of Petra in Jordan, albeit not nearly as expansive. A ‚Äònot to be missed‚Äô opportunity if ever visiting the beautiful Country of Sri Lanka ‚Ä¶

Exploring Sigiriya Lions Rock with kids was a delightful adventure! The captivating ancient ruins and panoramic views fascinated them, and the climb, though challenging, was manageable. The knowledgeable guide from Tourslanka ensured a family-friendly experience, making it an educational and enjoyable outing for all. Highly recommended for families!

Wow what an experience. Firstly you walk through the ancient gardens, ponds and ruins before initially climbing up the lions paws - after this it‚Äôs a little scary climbing the metal stairs to the top with people going in both directions but it‚Äôs well worth the effort for the views and ruins at the top. Highly recommended

column11: Experience the genuine warmth and kindness of Sri Lankan hospitality, where every guest is treated with love and care. you'll be showered with kindness and generosity that will make your stay unforgettable.

A must visit place!!! I was very impressed by the tour of Sigiriya. The climb itself is interesting and breathtaking. And the views are simply magnificent. If you are there in hot weather, be sure to take water with you.

One of the most astounding spot on the planet I have at any point been to. It's an exceptional encounter.To feel the nature and old setting of Lanka. The views and history were incredibly worth it.¬†this is a should visit place!

Like all sightseeing points the prices are quiet high especially for foreigners, for us from SAARC countries if you have your passport you get a 50% discount. The climb is overrated, young old and many seeming unfit easily reached the top, the fresco area behind the mirror wall opens later, so if you climb early and come down quick you will miss it. It is worth the effort of waking early and climbing as the views are spectacular.
Embark on an unforgettable Sri Lankan adventure with our loyal services and taxi transport. Explore vibrant landscapes and cultural wonders, creating lasting me

The Lion Fortress...for those who like history, they have a very pleasant time ahead of them. At first it's hard to climb a little but then you get used to it and it's not that big of a deal. The views are very cool and the city they set up there seems like a spiritual retreat...very interesting A visit to the frescoes seen on the way down is highly recommended. Approximately three hours of visit

To take in the whole experience, it's probably good to visit the museum and read a little about the history behind it. Another option is to take a guide with you who will tell you along the way. You will be offered a guide on site. There are many volunteers. The climb up the mountain is quite demanding but slow due to queues. There are both narrow stone stairs and iron stairs. Good shoes are highly recommended. Up on the mountain, the view is absolutely fantastic and you can see the ruins of the palace. I didn't know I was afraid of heights until it was time to climb down. Then you really SEE how high up you are! As this is a world heritage site, you should not miss the chance to visit the place.
What a majestic rock that rises beyond the forest. You have to like the steps to get to the top but the pleasure for the eyes will be guaranteed. A must-have
Departure during the night to enjoy the sunrise on the rock. Very beautiful site with beautiful ruins. 1000 steps but easily accessible

Stunning views and if you take the time to consider the engineering achievements it will v blow your mind. It‚Äôs certainly worthy of the title eighth wonder of the world. I would strongly recommend getting there early. The steps are tough enough for people who are fit. Add crowds , narrow staircases and hot weather it‚Äôs a tight day. Still awesome loved it

Who needs to read my review...: Sigiriya Rock is a simple 'must go, must see'. Only word of advice: go early, because it gets very busy later in the day. We arrived at 8 o'clock, which was early enough to beat the crowds, but late enough for the morning mist to mostly disappear. Spend one or two hours up the rock. And don't forget to visit the museum at the entrance afterwards.

The water gardens, cave and boulder gardens, and terraces gardens at Sigiriya are among the oldest landscaped gardens in the world, so be sure to check them out on the way to the rock. The ancient rock fortress dates back to the reign of King Kasyapa (477-495AD) and is pretty impressive, I would recommend a guide to understand the layout and features of the rock. It is a UNESCO heritage site and is being developed to improve the remaining features. I would recommend getting there early to avoid the crowds of the busy attraction. The 200 meter climb is not too strenuous but is uneven underfoot. The 1200 steps will be worth it when you get to the top and see the fantastic views of the jungle on all 4 sides, including views of the gardens below. The lions paws on the way up are pretty impressive too. Make sure you don‚Äôt miss the frescoes of the kings concubines on the way down, there are 18 remaining of the women opposite the mirrored wall. There are also numerous monkeys on the rock to see. An impressive place that you have to visit while in Sri Lanka.

The guide forced us to get up early, we were doubtful, but we arrived at the entrance to the site at 7: still few people, perfect temperature for the climb. This rock formation is located in the center of Sri Lanka and on it King Kassapa faithfully built an impregnable residence, after having deposed and had his father murdered. This reign lasted only about thirty years, the site was abandoned and was discovered by an English archaeologist in 1898. Of the residence there remain ruins on the top, and the paws of a gigantic lion halfway up (for this reason called LION ROCK). Halfway down the descent, in a recess, there are beautiful frescoes of breast-feeding concubines, of which unfortunately photography is prohibited.
The climb was interesting and adventurous. Quite a historic place with the wall paintings that were slightly fading off. Make sure you climb earlier in the day to avoid the boiling sun

A must do. Be in good health to go up...and down the 1233 steps. They are regular. Two intermediate platforms where you can rest. At the top, 360¬∞ view and very beautiful ruins. Be careful, at the top, no toilets or water

One of the best places I ever visited. Definitely a big WOW. The ticket price is expensive but every dollar is worth of spending. You need a guide to explain the locations and history. Don‚Äôt spend more than $20/- for a guide. The guide usually gets a commission on your purchases here. So make sure to bargain if you a buying a souvenir when the guide is escorting you. I noticed that some things which the guide mentioned was made up stories. But since the place is UNESCO verified, you can rely on the accuracy of documentation. Try to avoid public holidays and weekends as lots of local tourists visit there which makes the place congested and you will get stuck in long queues

I hired a driver from Kandy 3.5hrs. Stop at Cave temple first. The walk up can be busy and as of Jan 1, 2024 entrance is $36. The views are priceless yet wouldn't recommend unless staying in the area. It's a bit far for a day trip.
One of the best place to visit in Sri Lanka. I went there around 6 am to see the sunrise and top of the rock there is a old castle with many ruins. So much beautiful nature

Unfortunately picked a national holiday to visit - although was told weekend packed too. Finding the ticket office for foreigners required direction from our tuk tuk driver‚Ä¶. Surprised they make it difficult to help you part with $74 / couple. Then navigate your way through a sea of guides targeting ( naturally) western visitors. Not sure why you‚Äôd need one in the day light hours, just follow the thousands of locals (who pay next to nothing to climb).  Which wouldn‚Äôt be so bad were it not for their complete lack of any sense for queuing! Whilst the minority ( mainly western tourists) waited patiently at the pinch points of the climb, our local friends just casually walk past and formed their own scrummages. So annoying and off putting for tourists whose dollars help keep the economy afloat. The few tourists who ignored the queues were doing so at the instruction of their guides (who you would think know better and set. Standard for safety‚Äôs sake) Dangerous- why? No staff to set and  oversee any rules in an environment with multiple areas where fall to death is a real risk. The only person I saw resembling an official was there to stop photography in cave.  Otherwise people were left to pass each other on narrow stairs with no handrails in most cases.  Structurally I gasped at the corrosion on handrails posts where they did exist. With so many people leaning on these over shear drops I‚Äôm amazed that they haven‚Äôt yet failed. Come on you officials , spend some of those tourist dollars on this place to make it safe and restore this as the tourist attraction it was meant to be

I had a really bad experience. I was refused to enter Sigiriya Rock with my residence visa as a spouse of a Sri Lankan citizen. I was asked to pay the foreign price which is ridiculously high and as per the law I should be able to enter at the local price. All other tourist attractions in Sri Lanka accepted my residence visa and I was able to enter as a local rate ticket. This is all about money making at the Sigiriya Rock and this is not acceptable at all. The gentleman at the ticket counter was very unfriendly and not helpful at all and whenever he see the white skin people, he wants to charge the full foreign price and he don‚Äôt care about the residence visa. And he never let me to speak to his manager in charge of this place. Also all the other foreigners were really unsatisfied about the amount they had to pay. Anywhere else in the world there are no price differences between locals and foreigners. Sri Lankan tourism board should rethink about it if they want to implement the tourism in Sri Lanka. Facilities around the Sigiriya Rock is very poor according to the price.
One of the most amazing places in the world I have ever been to. It's a one of a kind experience. If you want to feel the nature and ancient context of Ceylon, this is a must visit place!

Great site to visit however the discrepancy between local tourist (120 LKR) and foreign tourist (11800 LKR) is ludicrous. Tips- get there by 6.45 am and go the museum and get tickets. The same tickets can be used in the museum later. The summit is a doable hike with multiple rest stop. There some areas where the fear of heights will definitely kick in. The frescoes can be seen either on the way down or at halfway point by turning to right. And following signs for exit. That way those with acrophobia can manage and still see the frescos.
Excellent place to visit. must be seen by everyone who visits Srilanka. Call my number for further details

The place is atmospheric, I really liked it. One can only imagine what a grandiose structure this was. The remains of the gardens are impressive. We only got up to our paws; we didn‚Äôt have enough strength for more, but what we saw was very impressive. I liked the preserved frescoes of beautiful young ladies.

We were a little worried after reading other reviews that this would be a disappointment with lots of 'hassle' from people wanting to sell you tours of the area. However we did not get asked once, it was an easier climb than expected and the views and history were incredibly worth it. An absolute must do for anyone of mid-range fitness and above.
Must do in Sigiriya. Recommend that you bring a bottle of water with you as it is very hot but the views are worth it. Took about 30 minutes on the way up at a slow pace.

The visit is quite nice (we did it without a guide). Unfortunately for us there were still quite a few clouds. Do it early in the morning or before closing to avoid extreme heat; climbing is still better! The frescoes are magnificent. On the other hand, for people who are afraid of heights, be aware that the stairs to get to the top are still steep. You must not look down.

This is a spectacular place and well worth it, BUT, if you arrive late you could be trapped behind a slow moving crowd, single-file, going at a sub-glacial pace. We decided to bail out when our guide estimated a 7-hour round trip. Instead, we came back the next morning, entered before 6, and were back down about 8:30, after a gorgeous, misty morning.

The place is interesting but be warned! Forget your manners and don‚Äôt greet the dodgy men who offer help to climb especially for women. Their intention is something else and no police there to ask for help . Shout them away. Then there are those begging you to accept them as your tour guide . They actually don‚Äôt know the history. So be cautious, be prepared.

It gets very crowded around mid-day, especially during weekends and public holidays. The climb itself is not that tough / long - but as the climbing route is narrow, crowds can significantly slow down the climbing process. Even small children and elderly people were seen climbing. The view while climbing and from the top is fantastic - greenery all around - there is a small pond and some view points on top to take pictures. One can easily spend half hour to 45 minutes at the top of the rock.
Must visit in Sri Lanka! The number 1 attraction we really enjoyed! Best way to get there - hire a driver.

This was a wonderful experience. Initially, I was worried as it was raining heavily when we left our hotel. Luckily the rain became lighter and stopped eventually. The gardens and terraces are well maintained.  Even though it gets crowded occasionally due to the steep steps going up and down, the views are amazing. I found it easier to take a guide as he explained everything nicely. Also I felt safer with his help as it was slippery due to the rain in places.

Our visit was a little affected by the sometimes pouring rain that accompanied us the entire time. This prevented us, at times, from taking an extra moment to enjoy the beauty before us, but this place still enchanted us: the site is spectacular, majestic, and in a spectacular natural setting. We start from three successive gardens, with which we begin to climb towards the "lion's" entrance: a steep staircase whose base is framed by two enormous lion's paws. On the fortress, there are representative rooms, swimming pools and the throne, arranged on terraces at different levels and surrounded by a splendid lush valley that dominates. The pearl is the frescoed rock environment. The ascent and descent are challenging, but definitely worth it.

Sigiriya is undoubtedly a site of historical and cultural significance with its breathtaking views and ancient ruins. However, the experience is somewhat overshadowed by the excessive crowds, which can detract from the site‚Äôs majestic aura. Additionally, the entrance fee of 30 USD per person feels steep, particularly for a site that often becomes overly congested. While the site itself is impressive, these factors make the visit less enjoyable than anticipated.
A must do. Amazing place with an abundance of history. Awesome views to take in from the top but also during the climb. 360* views of Sri Lanka.

Amazing and impressive. We arrived early and walked up and down. It took 1 1/2 hours. The views from the top are stunning. The walkway and steps are good. It has changed a lot since I last came here 20 years ago. We thought it would be sensible to book tickets online in advance and paid extra to do this. Do not do this. We still had to wait in the ticket queue to get paper tickets as they do not accept the electronic tickets at the gate. This took 40 minutes even though the queue was short. Don‚Äôt carry food. There are monkeys and they will try and take it. They are not scared at all. I saw a monkey take a whole packet of biscuits from someone.
Great place a must visit. Very nice lower park. From the very base of the cliff, the climb takes 20-30 minutes. We went up with children aged 3 and 5 years. The views at the top are worth the climb.

Getting up there after 1200 steps, very often irregular and slippery, was not easy...but when you get to the top the effort is rewarded by the spectacle you can enjoy and the majesty of the entire archaeological site...truly unmissable if you come to Sri Lanka ‚Ä¶
This is set in a lovely park and the fortress is awe inspiring. We are in our 70‚Äôs and climbed to the top with stops on the way. The views are beautiful and the setting incredible.
Definitely a challenging climb to the top but well worth it.  I would have been angry at myself if I didn‚Äôt do it.  The incredible wall murals made it even more worthwhile.

It lived up to our expectations. As impressive as in the pictures, in a beautiful landscaped setting. The climb was not as bad as we had been expecting which meant the whole experience will be a cherished memory. Don't miss it if you're visiting Sri Lanka.

We visited the ancient city in ruins with our local guide who explained to us all the details about the advanced system for the time, for cooling the rooms in the old palace and how to reserve water. Then we began the climb to the top of Lion Rock where the king's summer palace was located. The view is magnificent and despite the physical effort it is worth it.
Ishan did his best to show us all the important places while also respecting what we wanted to do next. He told us a lot about Sri Lanka and it‚Äòs history. We had a very nice day. Thank you!

Sigiriya in Sri Lanka is a mesmerizing testament to ancient ingenuity. As you arrive, parking is conveniently available, ensuring a hassle-free start to your visit. Guides, typically around 15-20 dollars depending on the season, add immense value, sharing insights while making the climb of approximately 3000 steps more engaging. Despite the ascent, the climb isn't overly strenuous, offering stunning vistas along the way. At the top, the breathtaking views of the surrounding landscape are simply unparalleled. Moreover, Sigiriya's significance intertwines with the legend of Ravana, a mythical figure from the Ramayana epic. Some believe that Sigiriya was initially associated with Ravana, adding a layer of mystique to its history, creating an allure that draws visitors seeking to uncover the mysteries of this ancient marvel.
Tourist attraction to absolutely recommend. Of course you have to be willing to climb all those steps!

Simply amazing. Helpful and knowledgeable guide took us up to see the sunrise. He identified and took care to help family members who were struggling a little with the ascent and descent Astonishing site, a must see Go early in the day to avoid the crowds and heat
It was simply brilliant. It is strenuous, but well developed and you just have to take enough time to climb to the top.

The ancient fortress is beautiful although it could be better maintained.Pace the climb as the rapid increase in altitude can cause dizzinesses. Preferably take water or an electrolyte drink with you. It is best to start the climb early(the place opens at 7am) as it gets very hot later in the day. The steps are steep and very narrow in places so wear comfortable footwear. It may be a hard climb for anyone with mobility issues but if you are reasonably fit this is a must do. Note: There are a whole bunch of guides hanging around the ticket place who quote anything from 5000-20000LKR. while we did hire a guide in hindsight I wouldn't recommend it. I took over a 100 photos and had all developed. There is photo opportunities at every step. The hike up and down took me about 3 hrs but I took my time, its steep but I'm used to hiking uphill. I can say it's safe but I would recommend being fit. The cost as I saw some complaining is NOT expensive of what you get to see. This is on the same scale as Machu picchu or chichennitza in cancun. So ignore those posts. $30is nothing to someone who comes from the west and travels that far!!. On a historical note this fortress dates 500 yrs before Christ. Once again, this fortress is an incredible place

I and my boyfriend are a living proof that this place is manageable even on a rainy day. Actually, the experience is amazing! There were almost no people, shorter or none queues. Just bring a raincoat or an umbrella, and open sandals, and you will be fine. The complex consists from the rock that you will climb using the famous stairs. In the second half of this journey, there is something called Mirror Wall and then frescoes, which is a small cave with very old pictures with still vivid colors. The place is full of self-employed tour guides - locals that will follow you around, saying that they are tour guides and that you definitely need one. Then they will walk with you, talk with you, and expect money at the end. We were warned that there is no need for a tour guide and that the place is mostly about walking the stairs and the view afterwards. Lion's Paws is the stairway where are normally those long lines of people that are trying to get to the top of the rock. At t the base of the stairs, there are statues in a form of lion's paws, so hence the name. This place is what you want to experience when someone talks about Sigiriya Rock. And form my experience, it's the biggest fun! The Mirror Wall itself is not that wow, I would say. It's not shiny anymore, you can't touch it, it's just therein its not shiny form. Frescoes that are waiting for you at the end of the line are much more interesting, since it's something to look at. The line leading to the frescoes is heading among the Mirror Wall. It's not possible to take pictures of frescoes, thought, there is a lot of staff watching everyone so nobody does it. I didn't see any toilets on the way, just those at the ticket office. So count with that, if you want to spend few hours of wondering at the place, or if the queues on the particular day are too long.

column11: It‚Äôs a well known rock on the tourist trail of Sri Lanka , but don‚Äôt let the crowds put you off, but go early to catch the morning light. This is a strenuous climb of stairs, metal staircases, and clambering of the ruins on the top, and anyone with vertigo might be advised not to do this, or those with weak stamina. That said it‚Äôs a fabulous view, and a great ruin with a nice history to it. You will be pestered by ‚Äòguides‚Äô offering to take you up there, but really they‚Äôre not necessary, and they want a tip of rupees for it. Basically you climb up the stairs ( over 1000!).

Dont go on a Full Moon holiday as crowds are huge!  But other than that expect to climb lots and lots of steps but well worth it for the view and to learn about the despot king who was carried around there and had 500 concubines too!

Beautiful ancient rock fortress! Easy climb. We really enjoyed the views. Only reason I‚Äôm giving it a 2 starts is because of our guide. We actually had a great time once he left us alone. Be careful with tour guides and ‚Äúhelpers‚Äù We had a man following us from the start and he was talking about the Sigiriya Rock. After approximately 5 minutes he stated that he was a freelance guide and offered to accompany us to the top while telling us about the history of this rock fortress. He stated that he didn‚Äôt have a price and we could decide at the end what to pay him depending on how we liked his services. We agreed. About 5 minutes after that he brought us to a man selling ‚Äúmagic boxes‚Äù and insisted we try to open them. We were not interested in buying any boxes. A few minutes after that his friend arrived and started ‚Äúhelping‚Äù me up the stairs. I did not ask for help nor was it needed.  He insisted on holding onto my hand however it was very awkward and opposite of helpful. It quickly became hazardous as none of the steps are the same size and walking with a stranger like that out of the blue was weird. This helping up the steps became annoying and I tried numerous times to stop it but he kept holding his hand out. My husband was actually walking behind us and thought it was the funniest thing.  It‚Äôs funny now looking back at it. He even snapped some photos. After a few more sets of steps I had to tell my husband that I am not climbing 1200 steps and up the rock like this. Luckily we were still in the beginning. My husband told our guide who translated to the helper that his assistance was not needed. We were then told he doesn‚Äôt work for free! Our guide then told us that his services were $40-$50! We paid less for a taxi drive with all our luggage from the airport to our hotel! Be careful! We told both of them to have a nice day however the guide still wanted money for his services ‚Äúthus far‚Äù   Ruins the experience!

we recently visited Sigiriya and would highly recommend it as a must-visit destination. The climb to the top of the rock is around 1200 steps, but it's well worth the effort for the incredible views across the forest. I would recommend visiting in the morning to avoid the heat and crowds, and to take advantage of the stunning sunrise views (start 5:30). While the entry fee is $30, I believe it's a reasonable price given the historical significance and beauty of the site. One thing to be aware of is that there are often many guides at the site who may hassle tourists, so it's best to be prepared for this and set clear boundaries. Overall, I found Sigiriya to be an amazing place to visit and would highly recommend it to others
